name: Let's get together and find out some of the ways R is used in Hamburg
description: This is the first meeting so the agenda is intentionally being kept open. There is no official language for this group. Comments in German are welcome, but group-level communications will be kept in English to welcome expats who may want to join.

name: Next quarterly meeting
description: After a successful kickoff, we're looking to seeing each other again as well as hopefully welcoming new faces. Two brief presentations will start off today's meeting, and then there will be time for mingling and group discussions like last time.

name: Third quarterly meeting
description:
A third meeting is already scheduled, and a detailed agenda will follow shortly.

If you would like to present on any topic for anywhere between 10-30 minutes feel free to get in touch.

venue.name: HSBA Hamburg School of Business Administration

name: 5th Quarterly meetup
description:
Two presentations are already booked:

Writing idiomatic R
P. Dente

From Matrix Algebra to Business Applications: Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) Explained and Applied with R.
M. Stanko

This means, however, there would be time for more. If you would like to present something, get in touch!

name: 7th Quarterly Hamburg R User Group Meetup
description:
Speakers at this event:

Integrating R and PowerPoint (David Geistert, Xing)

Collecting data from the internet: Web crawling and scraping with rvest and RSelenium (Dimitri Graf, TUHH Institute of Entrepreneurship)

description:

Unfortunately the announced "Rcpp-tutorial" by Marvin N. Vright must be postponed to our next meetup.

name: Free Workshop on Deep Learning with R
description:
With the release of the R Keras package (https://keras.rstudio.com/) (by JJ Allaire and Francois Chollet) at the end of 2017 / beginning 2018 the topic of artificial neural networks and especially deep learning in R became red-hot within the R community. (See also the new book on this topic (https://www.manning.com/books/deep-learning-with-r))

So we are very excited to announce a free Workshop on Deep Learning with Keras (and TensorFlow (https://www.tensorflow.org/)) in R at our next meetup. This workshop will be held by Michał Maj (https://www.linkedin.com/in/michal-maj116/), a Data Scientist in Appsilon Data Science (https://appsilondatascience.com) and is part of a series of pre-workshops of the Why R conference (http://whyr2018.pl/).

In this workshop you will learn answering the following questions:
• What are convolutional (CNN) and recurrent (RNN) neural networks?
• How to build and train neural networks using keras sequential_model() ?
• How to use Tensor Board for training visualizations?

Please make sure to bring your laptop including an up to date R version and run the following code in advance:
###-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Install libraries
packages <- c(
"tidyverse",
"jsonlite",
"abind",
"gridExtra",
"pracma",
"tokenizers",
"stringr",
"keras"
)
install.packages(packages)
library(keras)
###-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Setup Keras (Make sure to install required prerequisites, before installing # Keras using the commands below)
install_keras() # CPU version (recommended for beginners)
# install_keras(tensorflow = "gpu") # GPU version
###-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Please also download the following repository from github:
https://github.com/maju116/WhyR_Hamburg

Please note that the facilities for this workshop are limited to 80 participants (updated to 110) and we strongly encourage you to reliably register in advance for a better planning.

A special thanks goes also to Zalando ad tech (https://www.zalando-adtech-lab.com/), who welcome us at their wonderful venue (http://bit.ly/2GvYTmB).

name: R in production - Creating APIs with the plumber package
description:
Dear rusershamburg-community,

we are happy to invite you to our next meetup, which will take place on the 6th of June. This time we will address the broad topic of "R in production"

Roman Popat will be giving a short english tutorial/presentation on the `plumber`-package (https://github.com/rmnppt/plumber-tutorial). In his own words:

"Dear R novices and experts. Please join me at the meetup where I would like to discuss the suitability of R in production environments or among other technologies. I will give a live demo of the plumber R package (hats to Jeff Allen) used to expose your R code via a REST API. I will show you that this is very easy to do and then give you an account of my experience using it including its limitations and future prospects. Please also stick around for a wider discussion on R and its place in the technology mix. Looking forward to it."

Afterwards we will have a chance to discuss our own experiences with R "for production". We currently plan to collect some of YOUR questions before and address them together in an open discussion.
Please add your thoughts to https://github.com/rusershamburg/meetup-repo/edit/master/meetup-13/Readme.md and we will take it from there.

As always, we are very happy to welcome new R programmers to our group. Looking forward to meet you all in a couple of weeks!

PS:
A special thanks goes also to WeWork, who welcome and host us at their "Stadthaus" (directions: https://bit.ly/2rZdXlX) this time.

name: 14th Quarterly Meetup (Lightning Talks & Get together)
description:
This meetup won't be an official event, but rather an opportunity for everyone to get to know each other and exchange experiences about R.

We are going to meet at JobMatchMe and start with one or two lightning talks (more speakers are very welcome). Later on we will move to a restaurant in the closer vicinity.

name: Geocomputation with R, data science, open source software and geodata
description:
Hi everyone!

We are happy to announce our first Meetup in 2019 which will be held on Wednesday 9th of January, from 7pm (doors open at 6.45pm). The venue is JobMatchMe, Zirkusweg 2, 10th floor of the Astra Tower. As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome!

The agenda for this meetup is
1. Welcome / AOB
2. Robin’s talk + Q & A
3. 🍺 & 🍔 at http://www.thebirdinhamburg.com

Our speaker will be Robin Lovelace, geographer and environmental scientist specialising in spatial data analysis and computing. He will be discussing:

## Geocomputation with R, data science, open source software and geo data

This talk will introduce *Geocomputation with R*, a new book on using R to work with geographic data. It covers some of the key contents from the book and provides some examples of what is possible when geographic datasets are approached from a *data science* perspective, that ensures reproducibility. I'll show how working with geographic data has become much easier and more user friendly over the years, and demonstrate the importance of geographic data for informing policy.

name: "Using R to help plan the future of transport" & "easystats: Make R stats easy!"
description:
Hi everyone!

We are happy to announce our second Meetup in 2019 which will be held on Wednesday 13th of February, from 6.30pm (doors open at 6.15pm). The venue is JobMatchMe, Zirkusweg 2, 10th floor of the Astra Tower. As usual, the meeting will be open for all to attend, and newcomers / beginners are very welcome!

The agenda for this meetup is
1. Welcome / AOB
2. Mark’s talk + Q & A
3. Daniel's ⚡ talk + Q & A
4. 🍺 & 🍔 at TBA

In our first talk, Mark Padgham will provide an overview of several inter-related R packages for analysing urban dynamics:

## Using R to help plan the future of transport

The primary motivation for developing these packages has been their use in Active Transport Futures - a group of researchers and coders striving to aid cities to better plan for futures in which active travel, particularly walking and cycling, plays an increasingly prominent role (lots of open source code at github.com/ATFutures). We will take a close look at the packages "osmdata" and "dodgr", the first of which imports Open Street Map (OSM) data directly into R, while the second is a very powerful, large-scale routing engine. These two packages enable accurate estimates of densities of different kinds of transport along all individual street segments of a city. The development of these packages has been partly motivated by their use in the Urban Health Agenda of the World Health Organization. I will also demonstrate a few other tools currently being developed for this work, including a brand new package to very easily set up a web server for large amounts of spatial data, and finally one of our main current projects, moveability.city.

About the speaker: Mark has programmed in C++ for many years, and started using R as a way to get his code noticed by people, which seems to have worked. Along with several others, he is in the process of establishing moveability.city to provide a global-scale, open source platform to help cities transition towards environmentally and socially sustainable transport, and more equitable - and active - use of public space. He will be discussing:

Our second speaker will be Dr. Daniel Lüdecke. He will be discussing his new project of developing a suite of packages for statistics:

## easystats: Make R stats easy!

The aim of the project "easystats" is to provide a unifying and consistent
framework to tame, discipline and harness the scary R statistics and their
pesky models.

About the speaker: Daniel is a researcher at the "Institut für Medizinische Soziologie" at the UKE. Additionally he is a the author of several R packages including the sj familiy of packages.
